questions.neutral: You feel it too - something's off, right?

hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?
Origami help keep the noise out?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, I noticed it. Things are odd lately.
I just try to keep busy after work.
Sometimes I fold paper. It's simple, keeps my mind calm.
Crowds make it hard to focus, but habits help. That's all.
Definitely something in the air. People on edge.
I usually fold origami models to relax, but it’s gotten difficult.
Too many interruptions, lots of people talking after the assembly news.
Not much space left for quiet hobbies right now.
Paper folding helps me tune it all out, if I can.
Yeah, things have changed. Even here feels tense.
I spend evenings folding complex origami patterns—helps with the stress.
It’s not just cranes or boats, more like tessellations, modular stuff.
Crowds in the bar make it tricky but I still try.
Last week, folks kept asking to join. Guess everyone’s looking for calm.
Origami gives me something small I can control when everything else slips.
Everything’s different now, isn’t it? Even simple hobbies feel exposed.
I’ve been folding origami for years. The more intricate, the better.
Usually, it’s just for me—patterns, tessellations, complicated crease sequences.
After the assemblies started, people kept interrupting my sessions here.
I ended up teaching strangers how to crease paper instead of hiding.
It was odd, but for a couple hours the old pressure faded.
Now I carry spare paper for anyone who asks. Didn’t expect that.
You’re right. The whole city’s out of balance lately.
I started folding origami as a kid—first as distraction, now it’s a habit.
These days I work on complex geometric patterns, not just basic forms.
With the BCI acting up and assemblies growing, it’s been harder to focus anywhere.
Last week at this bar, several people joined my table for folding.
Strangers asked for help folding cranes—said it helped with their nerves.
Honestly, teaching them calmed me too. For a minute, it felt normal again.
Even when everything else is uncertain, the creases still line up if you’re careful.
hobby_answer: Yeah, origami helps. Keeps me even.
Still manage a fold or two when it's quiet enough.
Lately, too many people at the bar—more asking, fewer watching.
Crowds make small things feel exposed. I keep it simple now.
Suppose the city’s mood gets into everything, even the paper.
It is, most days. Folding gives structure. Something predictable.
Since the assemblies, more people want to join in—unexpected.
Sometimes I just want quiet. Too much attention isn't safe now.
Hard to get origami paper with ration changes. Using whatever scraps I find.
I keep practice private, don't trust digital logs of patterns.
Assemblies make folk friendlier, but also nosier.
Still my shield, yes. Folding patterns calms my head.
The bar’s busier since the assemblies started. People craving distraction.
With digital records a mess, everyone wants something tangible.
Ran an impromptu origami session last week. Wasn’t my plan.
Had to improvise paper, ration slips and receipts.
People talk more openly—maybe too openly. Fewer secrets, but more listening.
Funny how paper folds feel more secure now than my access badges.
Definitely still my shield. It's focus, order, escape.
This week, a group at Bar 101 joined without asking first—never happened before.
No proper paper left—ration slips, ballots, whatever we find now.
Feels different, folding alongside strangers. Less invisible, but somehow safer.
One girl pocketed a crane like it was luck against another outage.
With the system unstable, these moments mean more. Small certainties.
Sometimes I think I fold to hold together the part of me the Council can't track.
The city’s noise spills everywhere, but folding makes it quiet for a minute.
Origami is still my shield. Always has been, even before Directorate work.
Bar 101’s atmosphere has changed since the assemblies—less fear, more mess.
I used to fold for focus in isolation. Now groups form, asking for lessons.
With BCI down, everyone’s desperate to touch something real. Paper matters more now.
Ration slips, shopping lists—paper’s scarce, but we turn scraps into memories.
That night, for two hours, no one cared about scores or logs.
I caught myself wishing the old system would stay broken a bit longer.
Sometimes, folding is just survival. Sometimes, it’s protest. Depends on who notices.
If Halden was here, I doubt he’d imagine this—paper birds flying past the BCI crash.
